concept.title: What are databases?
concept.shortdesc: A short introduction in what databases are and how they are structured.

conbody.p: A database is a collection of data relating to a particular subject or a particular purpose. In a database you can store and track information from various sources, such as:

ul.li: Addresses of Customers in a address list
Telephone numbers of suppliers in a card catalog
Article data in a in a file cabinet
Orders of customers in a folder

conbody.p: All this information is often stored in separate tables that make up the database. In its simplest form a database table can be consist of only one table. Between the tables there could be relations and if so you can link data from different tables together. Such a database is called a relational database.

image.alt: Example of a relational database with three tables.

conbody.p: In addition to creating and maintaining tables you can also create forms, queries and reports. With forms, you can update information easily and efficiently. And with queries you can get answers on questions. Reports ensure that the output will be neatly displayed on screen or paper.

Access has the following components (objects) in a database:
Tables
Queries
Forms
Reports
Macro's
Modules
Access stores a database as a single file which contains all components of the database.

There are two different types of work carried out with databases:
Designing of the database This involves the creation of tables, queries, forms and reports. Once the database is created, this task is done.
Dealing with data Entering data, updating data, creating reports, searching in the database, etc.This work you are constantly doing.
